title: Rust is not able to infer equivalence when it applies to trait associated types.

labels.name: A-associated-items
labels.description: Area: Associated items such as associated types and consts.

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
This bug cause the error "overflowing when evaluating the requirement..."

Consider this example:

```rust
fn f<T, U>(v: T, u: U)
where
    T: Add<Output = <U as Add<U>>::Output>,
    U: Add<Output = <T as Add<T>>::Output>,
{
}
```

This does not compile: 
> error[E0275]: overflow evaluating the requirement <T as Add>::Output

The code above should compile because
the fact that `T` implements `Add` implies that there exits `A` such that `T:Add<Output=A>`
 
And this other definition for `f` does compile as expected.
```rust
fn f<T, U, A>(v: T, u: U)
where
    T: Add<Output = A>,
    U: Add<Output = <T as Add<T>>::Output>,
{
}
```
I think rust should be able to perform this transformation for the orginal f:
```rust
fn f<T, U>(v: T, u: U)
where
    T: Add,
  "there exists" A such that <T as Add>::Output = A,
    U: Add<Output = A>,
{
}
```

Maybe such transformation may also have a positive impact on compile time.


### Meta
This bug does exist on nightly too.

`rustc --version --verbose`:
```
rustc 1.52.1 (9bc8c42bb 2021-05-09)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: 9bc8c42bb2f19e745a63f3445f1ac248fb015e53
commit-date: 2021-05-09
host: x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu
release: 1.52.1
LLVM version: 12.0.0
```
